author: jimmygchen
content: <@785811170387951616> I’ve been thinking about the sync strategy you mentioned in the last call - I’m still not sure if it helps much under normal condition - but it could be very useful under non finality (holesky would’ve been more difficult to recover under peerdas) - if finding peers that serve the exact columns isn’t possible, it might help to get as many columns from the limited peer set on the same chain.

author: agnxsh
content: So for Nimbus I’m working on a flag that the user can optionally put while starting up the BN, there will be 2 modes Greedy and Impartial, Greedy is actively searching for better custody peers and always querying peers with the bigger intersection set.  Impartial doesn’t care who is a better peer it doesn’t calculate intersection it doesn’t even care about finality it simply asks whatever the peers can serve, reconstructs the rest of the columns, groups the columns under the common beacon block header and slot number, persists whatever it should locally custody and moves the slot needle.

author: agnxsh
content:
I’m not very sure either about it’s performance in normal conditions, there is a tradeoff that needs to be considered: the cpu overhead of computing intersections and thereby filtering out peers sending only range requests that are at all necessary vs sending many range requests, no filtering, based on what the remote peer can serve

IMO if i am a full node the second point looks worse than the first, if i have a good 2048eth+ node distribution 

However if I am a supernode i think the second strategy just wins big

In short a greedy sync would be faster but more dependent on the presence of specific peers, and an impartial sync would be slower but should be workable with just enough peers to custody half of all the columns

author: agnxsh
content: My rationale behind Impartial is since we advocate solo and home staking alot, it should pivotal for us atleast have a way of column syncing that aligns with values we believe in and can assist them with, that is rely more on full nodes, lesser resource players

author: jimmygchen
content: on the other hand - under normal conditions, i feel like this approach is going to put more unnecessary load on regular full nodes
